title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the National Anti-Drug Media Campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to rename it the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act. The amendments focus on preventing drug abuse among young people, increasing awareness of adults about the impact of drug abuse on youth, and encouraging discussions about the dangers of drug use. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to rename it and focuses on preventing drug abuse among young people. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the overall purposes and strategy of the national media campaign, with specific responsibilities outlined for implementation and approval. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to focus on preventing drug abuse among young people. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, recommends strategies for the national media campaign to address national, regional, and local drug threats. They also create advertising for the campaign, excluding ads provided by other nonprofits or intended for specific audiences that cannot be reached at no cost. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, recommends strategies for the national media campaign to address national, regional, and local drug threats. They also create advertising for the campaign and test all advertisements prior to use in the national media campaign to ensure effectiveness and meet industry standards. The Director enters into a contract with a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the campaign. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to focus on preventing drug abuse among young people. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America is unable to provide such advertisements, and there is a matching requirement for funds allocated for the national media campaign under section 106. The national media campaign under section 106 requires a no-cost match of equivalent value for advertising broadcast time and print space. The Director must ensure that all contributions directly relate to substance abuse prevention. Any donated advertising material is exempt from sponsorship identification provisions. Additionally, responsible use of federal funds is emphasized. The Director must ensure that at least 85% of funds are used for national media campaign advertising, with a cap of $5,000,000 for developing advertising material each fiscal year. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits and examinations of records, appoint an independent entity to evaluate the national media campaign, and submit a report to Congress. The Director must conduct audits, appoint an independent entity to evaluate the national media campaign, and submit a report to Congress. The Director is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign's strategy, accomplishments, efficiency, advertising plans, responsible fund usage, and contracts. Additionally, there is an authorization of $195,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 for the Office of National Drug Control Policy to carry out this subtitle.
